_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Ammonia Storage Tank, Liquid Piping, SCR System
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Indianapolis Power & Light, Petersburg is in compliance with OSHA Standard 29CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

The following engineering and administrative controls are in place to mitigate or reduce the amount of ammonia that would be released in case of an accident.

*  Ammonia detection is installed in appropriate tank farm locations. Detectors tie in to local audible alarms to alert process personnel of a potential hazard associated with an ammonia leak. Alarms also initiate investigation of the leak by ammonia system operators to determine it's origin and suppress it.
*  High and low liquid level switches are configured to all pressure vessels to alert SCR System personnel of a possible abnormal operating level within the associated vessel or the system.
*  Safety relief valves are installed on both ammonia storage vessels to eliminate the possibility of over-pressurization conditions.
*  Periodic maintenance program and written operating procedures are in place to ensure the ammonia system is maintained in an optimum operational and mechanical condition.
*  Operators make scheduled rounds throughout the 24 hour period checking equipment status and making appropriate log entries.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
AES/IPL - Petersburg, IN

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



I.   ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY POLICIES



IPL recognizes management's responsibility in protecting it's employees, equipment, property, and the environment against the hazards of an unintentional ammonia release. The safety and health of all employees and the public is very important.  The control of accidents has been and will continue to be a basic responsibility of all personnel in the facility.



The IPL PSM/RMP program assigns and documents the specific responsibilities for developing, implementing and  integrating the OSHA PSM and the EPA RMP standards into its safety program.  The IPL PSM/RMP program focuses attention on "Making PSM/RMP the way we manage" our ammonia based process rather than a project we expect to complete and put on the shelf when the filing date has passed.



IPL believes that Employee Participation is the key to a successful program.  Operating level employees, particularly the Operators and Maintenance personnel, will be deeply involved in the PSM/RMP program development, implementation and integration and they will assume a major responsibility for operating the ammonia process safely.



The IPL Emergency Response Program has been developed with the complete cooperation and support of the Pike Co. Local Emergency Planning Committee.  All IPL employees have received documented emergency action training.





II.  STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED



IPL operates a Fossil Fuel Power Generating Station.  Ammonia is used to control NOx emissions in their stack gas.   Anhydrous Ammonia is the only PSM/RMP chemical on site in amounts above the threshold quantity.





III.  DESCRIPTION OF THE IPL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



IPL conducts an annual training and response exercise to practice, train and update the IPL Emergency Response Program.



IPL conducts  triennial PSM/RMP compliance audits of the entire PSM/RMP program to identify strengths

and weaknesses and make improvements.  IPL considers the PSM/RMP manuals to be a collection of "living" documents that must be updated and revised regularly to maintain their viability.



IPL emphas and insists on "employee participation" from the ammonia system operators in all aspects of the development, implementation, and integration of their PSM/RMP program.



IPL provides a comprehensive, training program with full documentation specific training modules for each ammonia system employee.



IV.  FIVE YEAR ACCIDENTAL RELEASE HISTORY



There have been no releases of ammonia that resulted in an injury, or that had an off-site impact, or that resulted in significant property damage either on-site or off-site.



V.  Emergency Response Program



Facility employees have been trained to respond to accidental ammonia release.  The site emergency plan has been coordinated with the community emergency plan under the jurisdiction of the Pike Co.  Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC).



VI.  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



IPL recognizes that, even though their Ammonia release and injury experience has been excellent, their PSM/RMP program will provide much needed improvement to their safety effort. The PSM/RMP program is considered to be a set of "living" documents and procedures that will require constant attention, development, and revision before "Safety" becomes second nature.



IPL expects to improve safety performance by emphasizing the following elements of their PSM/RMP Program:



(1)   Employee Participation is the "Key" to a successful program.  Both the Maintenance and Ammonia System Operators will be deeply involved in verifying the P&IDs, Developing and updating the Standard Operating Procedures, and performing the documented Preventive Maintenance Inspections.



(2)    The IPL PSM/RMP Program will increasingly become:  (a) computer based,  (b) user friendly,  (c) based on specific training by qualified trainers,  (d) revised and re-writte

n to minimize paperwork and maximize documentation, and   (e) revised and re-written to be understood and used by the operating level employees.



(3)   All recommendations developed during the HAZOP were designed to improve the safety of the IPL facility.  IPL has evaluated each recommendation in a timely manner and has implemented those recommendations that will reduce the possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.
